title: How to Make Cumin & Sesame Roasted Potatoes

steps.headline: Peel potatoes and cut into desired shape.
steps.description: 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes is recommended, but large wedges or thick slices also work well.

steps.headline: If time permits, boil potatoes for 5-10 minutes to half cook them and then strain them in a colander.
steps.description: It's a trade off as this saves roasting time, but adds an extra stage to the cooking. It's not essential but it works well as it makes them crispier.

steps.headline: Mix cumin, sesame seeds and oils in a bowl.
steps.description: Stir well then add potatoes. Stir again to get an even coating on the spuds. It's perfectly good if the surface of the potato gets "roughened up" as it makes them crispier. Add a little more peanut oil if the mix seems too dry for a good coating.

steps.headline: Tip onto the lined baking tray and spread out.
steps.description: If your oven is known for burning things, cover with foil.

steps.headline: Baking varies according to the oven and size of your potato cut.
steps.description: If you half cooked them, 20-30 minutes is all you would need, but 30-40 minutes for raw or for large wedges.

steps.headline: Keep checking and shake the tray now and then while cooking to make them cook evenly.
steps.description: When they are golden brown and cooked through (test with a skewer) then they are ready to go.

steps.headline: Season well with salt and pepper and serve.
steps.description: See tips for extra serving of flavour suggestions.

text: Peel potatoes and cut into desired shape. 1 inch (2.5 cm) cubes is recommended, but large wedges or thick slices also work well. Preheat oven to approx 220C / 428F.  If time permits, boil potatoes for 5-10 minutes to half cook them and then strain them in a colander. It's a trade off as this saves roasting time, but adds an extra stage to the cooking. It's not essential but it works well as it makes them crispier. Mix cumin, sesame seeds and oils in a bowl. Stir well then add potatoes. Stir again to get an even coating on the spuds. It's perfectly good if the surface of the potato gets "roughened up" as it makes them crispier. Add a little more peanut oil if the mix seems too dry for a good coating. Tip onto the lined baking tray and spread out. If your oven is known for burning things, cover with foil. Baking varies according to the oven and size of your potato cut. If you half cooked them, 20-30 minutes is all you would need, but 30-40 minutes for raw or for large wedges. Keep checking and shake the tray now and then while cooking to make them cook evenly. When they are golden brown and cooked through (test with a skewer) then they are ready to go. Season well with salt and pepper and serve. See tips for extra serving of flavour suggestions.
